title: UNIX System Services
text:
z/OS UNIX System Services (z/OS UNIX, or informally USS) is a required, included <a href="software%20componentry">component</a> of <a href="z/OS">z/OS</a>. z/OS UNIX is a certified <a href="Unix">UNIX</a> <a href="operating%20system">operating system</a> implementation (<a href="XPG4">XPG4</a> UNIX 95) optimized for mainframe architecture. It is the first <a href="UNIX%2095">UNIX 95</a> to not be derived from the <a href="AT%26amp%3BT%20Corporation">AT&T</a> source code. Through integration with the rest of z/OS, additional <a href="Time%20Sharing%20Option">Time Sharing Option</a> (TSO) commands are available alongside the usual UNIX services, making it possible to process UNIX files using <a href="ISPF">ISPF</a>. Extensions in <a href="Job%20Control%20Language">JCL</a> make it possible to use these files in <a href="batch%20processing">batch processing</a>.
Overview.
UNIX System Services allows UNIX applications from other platforms to run on <a href="IBM%20System%20z">IBM System z</a> mainframes running z/OS. In many cases only a recompile is necessary, although additional effort may be advisable for z/OS integration (such as <a href="SMP/E">SMP/E</a> installation support). While z/OS UNIX supports ASCII and <a href="Unicode">Unicode</a>, and there's no technical requirement to modify ASCII and Unicode UNIX applications, many z/OS users often prefer <a href="EBCDIC">EBCDIC</a> support in their applications including those running in z/OS UNIX. Consequently, z/OS UNIX provides application and administrator services for converting to/from EBCDIC. Programs running under z/OS UNIX have full, secure access to the other internal functions of z/OS. Database access (<a href="IBM%20DB2">DB2</a> via Call Attach) is one example of how z/OS UNIX can access services found elsewhere in z/OS. Naturally such programs cannot be ported to non-mainframe platforms without rewriting if they use these z/OS-specific services. Conversely, if a program adheres to UNIX standards such as POSIX and <a href="ANSI%20C">ANSI C</a>, it will be easier to move it between different UNIX operating systems including z/OS UNIX.
The file systems for z/OS UNIX (the older <a href="Hierarchical%20File%20System%20%28IBM%20MVS%29">HFS</a> and the now preferred <a href="ZFS%20%28z/OS%20file%20system%29">zFS</a>), which support UNIX-style <a href="long%20filename">long filename</a>s, appear as special <a href="VSAM">VSAM</a> <a href="Data%20set%20%28IBM%20mainframe%29">dataset</a>s to the rest of z/OS. Numerous core z/OS subsystems and applications rely on UNIX System Services, including the z/OS Management Facility, XML parsing and generation services, <a href="OpenSSH">OpenSSH</a>, the IBM HTTP Server for z/OS, the z/OS SDK for <a href="Java%20%28programming%20language%29">Java</a>, and some z/OS PKI services as examples. z/OS UNIX also provides a <a href="Shell%20%28computing%29">shell</a> environment, OMVS.
z/OS UNIX's predecessor was an operating system component called <a href="MVS%23MVS.2FESA">OpenEdition MVS</a>, first implemented in <a href="MVS/ESA">MVS/ESA</a> 4.3 and enhanced in <a href="MVS/ESA">MVS/ESA</a> 5.1. OpenEdition MVS only supported the <a href="POSIX">POSIX</a> standards.
IBM continues to enhance UNIX System Services. Typically every release of z/OS includes enhancements to z/OS UNIX.
